Students: Lily Cordner, Sammy Hankaoui, Delainey O'Connor, Emily Pollock, Blake Wofford
Title: A Preliminary Analysis of Healthcare Disparities Curriculum at WPI
Abstract: Undergraduate bioengineering and biomedical sciences curriculum is currently lacking the inclusion of healthcare disparities education. It is imperative to educate future healthcare professionals as early in their career as possible in order to mitigate these disparities in their later work. The purpose of this study was to look at the degree and manner in which students have intersected with healthcare disparities. Another focal point of the study was to examine the effectiveness of an educational module administered to students taking courses in biomedical sciences, bioengineering, and adjacent disciplines.

Students: Isabel Bowman, Kendall Pacheco, Javier Sibel, Ziyan Xie
Title: Impact Mouthguard Sensor to Detect Real Time Rotational and Linear Acceleration
Abstract: Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) occur when a force acts upon your head resulting in two forms of acceleration through the skull. These blows are characterized by linear and rotational acceleration. There is currently no prevention for TBIs, but there are treatments to aid the symptoms that go along with the injury. Studies show that the more TBIs that one person obtains, the more severe the damage could be, ultimately leading to CTE which could be fatal. The goal of this project is to produce a device that will measure head impact through a mouthguard sensor that will detect rotational and linear acceleration in real-time. This product can be utilized for any contact or collision sports for youth up to professional athlete.

Title: Characterizing Composite Microthreads
Abstract: Discrete fibrin microthreads are a type of matrix scaffold that offer the potential to address volumetric muscle loss when used as a scaffold for muscle tissue. One way to optimize these mircrothreads would be to incorporate the delivery of drugs, antibiotics, or growth factors from the threads, as it would provide benefits to the local implantation site. Silk fibroin is a material that has been widely used in drug delivery and offers tunable properties and the ability to deliver a variety of molecules and proteins. The goal of this project was to investigate and characterize the use of silk microparticles as a composite material when incorporated into fibrin microthreads.

Advisors: Izabela Stroe, Maqsood Mughal, Amhet Can Sabuncu, Cagdas Onal
Title: An Endoscopy Probe for Early Colorectal Cancer Detection
Abstract: Colonoscopies are routine procedures for many adults. For individuals with IBD these procedures are annual. Polyps or precancerous tissue is missed the most in this population as their inflamed bowels make it difficult to detect these regions. Cancerous tissue development is associated with increased conductivity as tight junction activity increases the flow of ions. We developed a coaxial probe to scan electrical properties of tissues, like conductance. The proposed design would be incorporated with current colonoscopes and fed through the working channel of these devices. Future studies will be required to test the device's ability to differentiate cancerous tissue.

Students: Jenna Currie, Thomas Lipkin, Dana Landry, Sarah Vasquez
Advisors: Pradeep Radhakrishnan, Dirk Albrecht, Kaveh Pahlavan
Title: Investigating the Use of Magnetic Actuation to Develop a Functional Tongue Prosthetic to Mimic Human Deglutition
Abstract: The goal of this project is to utilize magnetic actuation to create a functional tongue prosthetic for oral cancer patients. Glossectomy is a surgical procedure in which the tongue is removed mainly due to cancer and has affects on the eating and speaking of patients. Currently, tongue prosthetics are static and lack any functionality. Our project aimed to miniaturize the electrical components to fit within the oral cavity and move the prosthetic to aid with feeding. Magnetic actuation was explored and utilized as the method of movement.

Title: Metalinguistic Awareness & Language Learning
Abstract: Learning a second language typically makes learning a third easier. The hypothesized reason for this improved language learning ability is metalinguistic awareness: the ability to consciously and explicitly think about linguistic form, such as the grammar of a language. The goal of this project is to investigate the relationship between metalinguistic awareness, multilingualism, and language learning. I designed a series of English-language tasks, including a think-aloud protocol, and survey of language learning experiences. Forty-eight adults (L1 English: 27 participants) completed the research study. This research can inform educators and learners alike on how metalinguistic awareness can improve language learning outcomes.

Students: Brooke Dawson, Amelia Harvey, Aram Soultanian, Hannah Gallagher, Lilly Nardelli
Title: Redesigned Shark Tagging
Abstract: Great white sharks are an apex predator of the marine ecosystem. Researchers today are trying to develop a deeper understanding of their migration patterns and predatory habits to keep beaches safer for humans. This project partnered with MA Division of Fisheries and Dr. Greg Skomal, to create a tagging mechanism to attach a CATS Cam sensor system to the dorsal fin of a great white. The safety of the user and the shark were of utmost importance in the design process. Iterations of a pole design were modelled in CAD, fabricated and tested with 3D printed plastics, and manufactured with machining equipment. This project paves the way for further data collection on great whites, leading to more awareness and predictability of shark locations.

Students: Lorrie Ataya, David Burgos, Angela Haith, Bryce Wade
Title: A Bicycle for Every Kid
Abstract: Muscular disabilities result in weakness and inhibit mobility. Adaptations to the standard bicycle exist, but their functions are focused on therapeutic purposes. Therefore, the project goal was to create a fun and functioning modified children's bicycle. This was validated through the assessment of functions, objectives, and constraints, as well as research and client outreach. Due to COVID, we selected two major components to focus on: the propulsion and turning mechanisms. The resulting product consisted of a working prototype that demonstrated the necessary functions. Recommendations include the material modification and safety improvement. The resulting appearance was also modified cosmetically to further reduce stigma.

Students: Isabelle Jaquith, Erica Houghton, Brittany Bolster, Christina Freni, Sofia Orrico
Title: Testing Method and Fixtures for Comparing Fatigue Loading Conditions in Bones
Abstract: Bone stress injuries occur when the bones cannot tolerate repeated mechanical loads. As a result, structural fatigue accumulates at the site of the injury. This kind of injury is common in athletes, accounting for 10% of orthopedic injuries. This study examined how human metatarsals may react under repeated mechanical loading using avian bones. To achieve this, a design and test fixture were developed to model the physiological conditions and loading in the metatarsals. Subject testing of avian bones were used to calculate damage accumulation after up to 30,000 cycles. This damage was used to identify the mechanical properties of bone under cyclic loading, informing preventative methods and treatment for bone stress injuries in humans.

Title: Partial Hand Prosthetic
Abstract: The goal of this project was to develop a partial hand prosthetic for an amputee from Texas who was told she there were no commercially available options. Her amputation was unique in that her entire index finger was removed leaving no metacarpal to actuate a device, the method of most devices. This project explored various ways of actuating her two missing digits (index and thumb), resulting in the movement of her index finger being coupled to that of her middle finger, and the movement of the thumb controlled through pressure sensors which rest atop her metacarpal. The device also uses novel passive variable bladders in order to ensure that the harness remains stable on her hand as the index finger experiences resistance.

Students: Rachel Arnold, Trevor Karrett, Chloe Melville
Title: Ischemic Stroke Detection
Abstract: Each year 795,000 Americans suffer from a stroke, 87% of them being ischemic where a blood clot travels from the heart to the brain causing irreparable damage. The potentially fatal consequences of these strokes could be avoided with early detection and removal of the clot. We developed phantom models of the neck and carotid artery for testing. Artificial blood and clots were pumped through the model, and an ultrasound probe connected to a computer running a computer vision algorithm was used to detect them. Our proof of concept shows that a wearable device could be created to preemptively detect ischemic strokes for at risk patients.

Students: Samantha Morton, Leah White, Alyssa Webb, Julia Premo, Alexa Eves
Title: Gompei's Lab-Grown Leather
Abstract: The goal of this project is to reduce waste in the current leather making process through the establishment of a device capable of cell seeding on a plant scaffold while additionally allowing for the perfusion of media. The current leather making process poses as a detriment to society given the vast amount of waste and excess harmful chemicals that are produced from the process. Researchers aim to understand the dynamics of growing bovine dermis and its mechanical properties well enough to produce a device capable of growing a sheet of lab-grown leather. The results of our device will be compared to the current leather making process.
